tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"Raise a shout to Yahweh." See how "shout" is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:047:001|47:1]].
This refers to all the people of the earth. AT: "everyone on the earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

The psalmist speaks as if he is telling the readers to go into the throne room of a king. AT: "go to where he is with joyful singing" or "he can hear you, so sing joyfully" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
God's people are like his sheep. AT: "the people God provides for and protects" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
a grassy area for feeding animals
"while thanking him" or "while giving thanks to him"

The word "name" is a metonym for Yahweh himself. AT: "bless Yahweh" or "do what makes Yahweh happy." See how "may his glorious name be blessed" is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:072:018|72:19]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"generation after generation." See how this is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:089:003|89:4]].
